dt: {bc}to make familiar {bc}to cause to know firsthand

dt.t: {wi}acquainting{/wi} the new employees with their responsibilities
She took a few days to {wi}acquaint{/wi} herself with the facts of the case.

pt: {sc}inform{/sc} {sc}acquaint{/sc} {sc}apprise{/sc} {sc}notify{/sc} mean to make one aware of something. {sc}inform{/sc} implies the imparting of knowledge especially of facts or occurrences.
{sc}acquaint{/sc} lays stress on introducing to or familiarizing with.
{sc}apprise{/sc} implies communicating something of special interest or importance.
{sc}notify{/sc} implies sending notice of something requiring attention or demanding action.

et: Middle English {it}acoynten, aqueynten,{/it} borrowed from Anglo-French {it}acuinter, acointer, aqueinter,{/it} going back to Vulgar Latin {it}*accognitāre,{/it} frequentative formation from the base of Latin {it}accognōscere{/it} "to recognize," from {it}ad-{/it} {et_link|ad-|ad-} + {it}cognōscere{/it} "to get to know" {ma}{mat|cognition|}, {mat|quaint|}{/ma}
shortdef: to make familiar : to cause to know firsthand

dt.t: The lawyer took a few days to {it}acquaint herself with{/it} the facts of the case.
